questions.stimulus: (1) The salt spray was cool on Maya’s face as she and her younger brother, Leo, explored the tide pools on Dragon’s Tooth. (2) This rocky finger of land only appeared during the lowest tides, and Maya loved the strange creatures left behind. (3) "Look!" Leo shouted, pointing at a starfish. (4) Maya smiled, but her eyes kept drifting to the western sky, which was turning a bruised, greenish-purple. (5) "The wind is changing," she said, her voice suddenly tight. (6) It wasn't just changing; it was howling. (7) In moments, the calm sea churned into a grey, angry mess. (8) The tide, which should have been hours away, began to surge, swallowing the sandbar that connected them to the main beach. (9) "Maya, we're trapped!" Leo cried, his voice barely audible over the roar of the waves. (10) He was right. The path back was gone, replaced by crashing surf. (11) Panic, cold and sharp, pricked at Maya. (12) She looked at Leo's terrified face, and her own fear turned into resolve. (13) "It's okay," she yelled. (14) "I know another way. The old smuggler's path. It's steep, but it will get us up the cliff." (15) Rain began to lash down, making the dark rocks slick and treacherous. (16) Maya grabbed Leo's hand. (17) "Don't look down. Just follow my feet." (18) The climb was a blur of wind, rain, and fear. (19) At one point, Leo froze, his small body trembling. (20) "I can't!" he sobbed. (21) A massive wave exploded against the rocks just feet below them, sending a cold sheet of spray over them. (22) "Yes, you can!" Maya shouted, her voice firm. (23) "You are brave. Now, climb!" (24) Fueled by her command, Leo scrambled up. (25) They didn't stop until they collapsed, soaked and shaking, on the grassy bluff high above the storm. (26) They were safe. (27) Leo looked at his sister, his eyes wide with something more than fear. (28) It was respect.
questions.stem: How does the setting of Dragon's Tooth directly create the main conflict of the story?
options: It is a place with many strange creatures to see.
It is a place that becomes a dangerous island during a sudden storm.
It is a place where Maya and Leo often go to explore.
It is a place with a steep cliff and a grassy bluff.

questions.stem: In sentences 11-12, how does Maya's character change in response to the conflict?
options: She becomes angry at Leo for being scared.
She panics and is unable to think clearly.
She uses her fear to become more determined and lead.
She decides to wait for the storm to pass.

part1.stem: Which sentence best describes how the conflict with nature (the storm) impacts the plot?
options: It makes Maya and Leo decide to go home early.
It forces Maya to use her knowledge and courage to find a new way to safety.
It shows that exploring tide pools is a dangerous hobby.
It causes Leo to respect his sister more.

part2.stem: Which sentence from the text best supports the answer to Part 1?
options: "(4) Maya smiled, but her eyes kept drifting to the western sky..."
"(9) 'Maya, we're trapped!' Leo cried, his voice barely audible over the roar of the waves."
"(14) 'I know another way. The old smuggler's path. It's steep, but it will get us up the cliff.'"
"(27) Leo looked at his sister, his eyes wide with something more than fear."

questions.stem: Which two elements of the setting work together to make the conflict more dangerous?
options: The "bruised, greenish-purple" sky
The "starfish" in the tide pool
The "surging" tide
The "slick and treacherous" rocks
The "grassy bluff"

questions.stem: Read sentences 4-8. Click on the sentence that marks the main turning point where the setting clearly changes and begins the conflict.

sentences.text: (4) Maya smiled, but her eyes kept drifting to the western sky, which was turning a bruised, greenish-purple.
(5) "The wind is changing," she said, her voice suddenly tight.
(6) It wasn't just changing; it was howling.
(7) In moments, the calm sea churned into a grey, angry mess.
(8) The tide, which should have been hours away, began to surge, swallowing the sandbar that connected them to the main beach.

questions.stem: How does Leo's character (his fear) affect the plot?
options: It causes the storm to get worse.
It creates an extra challenge that Maya must overcome.
It helps Maya find the smuggler's path.
It makes Leo the hero of the story.

questions.stem: What is the most likely reason the author includes the detail about the "old smuggler's path" (sentence 14)?
options: To show that Maya breaks the rules and is a troublemaker.
To provide a believable way for the characters to resolve the conflict.
To suggest that smugglers are still on the island.
To explain why the cliff is so steep and treacherous.

questions.stem: The plot develops as the conflict gets worse and is then solved. Drag the events into the correct order as they happen in the story.

draggables.text: Maya must encourage a frozen Leo to keep climbing.
Maya and Leo are exploring the tide pools.
Maya and Leo collapse safely on the grassy bluff.
The tide surges and traps them on Dragon's Tooth.

questions.stem: Which two details best show how Maya's character (her leadership) directly moves the plot toward a solution?
options: ...her eyes kept drifting to the western sky...
"Panic, cold and sharp, pricked at Maya."
"'I know another way. The old smuggler's path.'"
"Maya grabbed Leo's hand."
"'Yes, you can!' Maya shouted, her voice firm."

questions.stem: Explain how the climax (the most intense part) of the story is created by both the setting (the storm) and the conflict between Maya and Leo (his fear).
